What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: a lot of real world applications of statistics
I brushed up on techniques we had learned in our previous classes, and I learned how to code more mindfully and conduct a research project from beginning to end.
Better coding practices and applied data science skills.
practical data analysis skills
Statistical modeling and application to real world data, extensive familiarity with R programming language

This course was pretty all over the place and I don't think we learned that many useful skills. We didn't get much helpful feedback, most of it seemed to focus on nit picking comment format aesthetics rather than functionality of the code we wrote.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: professor emerson is really great, i like how it wasn't very structured and more open ended
The strength of this course was the small group meetings we had with Professor Emerson.
The teaching is great. I wish there was a little more direction on some assignments.
a realistic setting to practice data analysis; projects are given and you just go at it in groups
Does a good job of forcing you to adopt good programming behavior and think creatively to solve real world problems. Some of the questions and grades felt more like gotchas than actually teaching

Jay refused to provide and answer key for one of the homeworks initially because "that's how the real world works." It was pretty frustrating to receive a grade and no feedback about where that grade came from and being told to figure it out, when clearly we all gave our best attempt already. There was also no common theme to the class other than the formatting of code and very basic R functionality. The industry doesn't even use R anymore, and the adamant opposition to using any packages did not enhance our understanding in any meaningful way. To be honest, I have no idea how this is considered a capstone class given how incredibly basic the material is. We spent a very long time doing web scraping with R, and there was very little opportunity to actually use the more advanced concepts we learned in the major.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Well structured for the pandemic. No need to change.

Virtual lectures were fine, but not recording them was questionable, as not everyone is on US time. Forcing everyone to attend live during a paemic when class happens at midnight for some is not a good practice

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Better than doing a thesis in the major if you really don't want to, but nothing thrilling. Professor Emerson can be a bit intense and condescending at times. We had a problem set that he refused to give us answers for as he felt that is what the real world would be like. I often felt like I would be scoffed at when asking a question until towards the end. It may not be out of malice, but he can be cold. There isn't much teaching that goes on in the course either, you'll learn more from working through assignments with friends than you will in seminar.
great course for any stats major
Yes.

Yes! Professor Emerson is both incredibly helpful and practical when it comes to data analysis in R. Not much work outside of class: pretty much all projects are done in class in breakout rooms with others. Projects are reasonable and lots of fun.
You're taking this cource because you don't want to write a thesis. Not like you have a choice.
No, but it was definitely easier than doing a senior thesis.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual Class.
